metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: Redox reactions as simultaneous oxidation and reduction processes, and the use of oxidation numbers to identify the reducing agent, oxidising agent and conjugate redox pairs

redox_definition.name: Redox Reaction Definition
redox_definition.correct: A redox reaction involves the simultaneous transfer of electrons between species. One species loses electrons (oxidation) while another gains electrons (reduction).

only oxidation occurs.error: Oxidation cannot happen alone. Electrons must go somewhere.
only oxidation occurs.fix: Electrons lost by one species must be gained by another. Both processes occur together.
only oxidation occurs.action: Ask: if electrons leave one species, where do they go? Answer: to another species.

only reduction occurs.error: Reduction cannot happen alone. Electrons must come from somewhere.
only reduction occurs.fix: Electrons gained by one species must come from another. Both processes are linked.
only reduction occurs.action: Ask: if a species gains electrons, where do they come from? Answer: from another species.

proton transfer occurs.error: Proton transfer is acid-base chemistry, not redox.
proton transfer occurs.fix: Redox = electron transfer. Acid-base = proton transfer. Different reaction types.
proton transfer occurs.action: Key distinction: redox involves e⁻, acid-base involves H⁺.

persistent.gap: You're not recognising that oxidation and reduction are inseparable.
persistent.action: For every redox equation, identify both the species oxidised AND reduced. They always come in pairs.

oxidation_definition.name: Oxidation Definition
oxidation_definition.correct: Oxidation is the loss of electrons. Remember OIL RIG: Oxidation Is Loss (of electrons).

gain of electrons.error: Reversed. Gain of electrons is reduction, not oxidation.
gain of electrons.fix: OIL RIG: Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain.
gain of electrons.action: Write OIL RIG on your notes. Oxidation = electrons LEAVING.

gain of oxygen.fix: Modern definition: oxidation = loss of electrons. Gaining oxygen often involves losing electrons, but not always.
gain of oxygen.action: Use electron transfer definition. It works for ALL redox reactions.

loss of oxygen.error: That's the old definition of reduction, not oxidation.
loss of oxygen.fix: Loss of oxygen can indicate reduction. Oxidation = loss of electrons.
loss of oxygen.action: Focus on electrons, not oxygen atoms.

persistent.gap: You're confusing oxidation and reduction definitions.
persistent.action: Memorise OIL RIG. Test yourself: oxidation = loss or gain? Answer: LOSS.

reduction_definition.name: Reduction Definition
reduction_definition.correct: Reduction is the gain of electrons. Remember OIL RIG: Reduction Is Gain (of electrons).

loss of electrons.error: Reversed. Loss of electrons is oxidation, not reduction.
loss of electrons.fix: OIL RIG: Reduction Is Gain, Oxidation Is Loss.
loss of electrons.action: Reduction = electrons ARRIVING at a species.

gain of oxygen.error: That's the old definition of oxidation, not reduction.
gain of oxygen.fix: Gaining oxygen often means losing electrons = oxidation. Reduction = gaining electrons.

loss of hydrogen.error: Loss of hydrogen often indicates oxidation, not reduction.
loss of hydrogen.fix: Reduction = gain of electrons. Don't rely on hydrogen or oxygen changes.

persistent.gap: You have oxidation and reduction swapped in your mind.
persistent.action: Write 10 half-equations. Label each as oxidation (e⁻ on right) or reduction (e⁻ on left).

oxidation_number_free_element.name: Oxidation Number of Free Elements
oxidation_number_free_element.correct: Free elements (uncombined, not in compounds) have an oxidation number of zero. This includes diatomic molecules like O₂, H₂, N₂, and metals like Fe, Cu, Zn.

+1.error: Free elements have oxidation number 0, not +1.
+1.fix: Uncombined elements haven't lost or gained electrons yet. Oxidation number = 0.
+1.action: Fe(s), O₂(g), H₂(g), Cu(s) all have oxidation number 0.

-1.error: Free elements have oxidation number 0, not -1.
-1.fix: An element on its own has no charge redistribution. Oxidation number = 0.
-1.action: Only when combined with other elements do oxidation numbers become non-zero.

equal to group number.error: Group number applies to ions and compounds, not free elements.
equal to group number.fix: Free elements = 0. Group number helps predict oxidation states in compounds.
equal to group number.action: Na metal = 0. Na in NaCl = +1 (group 1 ion).

persistent.gap: You're not recognising when elements are 'free' vs combined.
persistent.action: List 10 free elements (Fe, Cu, O₂, etc.) and confirm each has oxidation number 0.

oxidation_number_oxygen.name: Oxidation Number of Oxygen
oxidation_number_oxygen.correct: Oxygen typically has oxidation number -2 in compounds. Exception: in peroxides (like H₂O₂), oxygen has oxidation number -1.

-1 in all compounds.error: -1 is only for peroxides. Most compounds have oxygen at -2.
-1 in all compounds.fix: Default: O = -2. Exception: peroxides (H₂O₂, Na₂O₂) have O = -1.
-1 in all compounds.action: Unless you see a peroxide, assume oxygen is -2.

+2.error: Oxygen is highly electronegative. It gains electrons, giving negative oxidation numbers.
+2.fix: Oxygen almost always has negative oxidation numbers (-2 or -1).
+2.action: Oxygen is second most electronegative element. It attracts electrons.

0 in all compounds.error: 0 is only for free O₂. In compounds, oxygen has -2 (or -1 in peroxides).
0 in all compounds.fix: Once oxygen is combined with other elements, its oxidation number changes from 0.
0 in all compounds.action: O₂(g) = 0. H₂O = -2 per oxygen. H₂O₂ = -1 per oxygen.

persistent.gap: You're not applying oxygen's oxidation number rules correctly.
persistent.action: Practice: assign oxygen's oxidation number in H₂O, CO₂, MgO, H₂O₂. Answers: -2, -2, -2, -1.

oxidation_number_hydrogen.name: Oxidation Number of Hydrogen
oxidation_number_hydrogen.correct: Hydrogen typically has oxidation number +1 in compounds. Exception: in metal hydrides (like NaH), hydrogen has oxidation number -1.

-1 in all compounds.error: -1 is only for metal hydrides. Most compounds have hydrogen at +1.
-1 in all compounds.fix: Default: H = +1. Exception: metal hydrides (NaH, CaH₂) have H = -1.
-1 in all compounds.action: In water, acids, organic compounds: H = +1. Only with metals: H = -1.

+2.error: Hydrogen only has one electron to lose, so maximum is +1.
+2.fix: H has 1 valence electron. It can only lose 1 electron → +1 maximum.
+2.action: Check hydrogen's electron configuration: 1s¹. Only one electron available.

0 in all compounds.error: 0 is only for free H₂. In compounds, hydrogen is +1 (or -1 in metal hydrides).
0 in all compounds.fix: H₂(g) = 0. In compounds, H shares or transfers its electron.

persistent.gap: You're not applying hydrogen's oxidation number rules correctly.
persistent.action: Practice: assign H's oxidation number in H₂O, HCl, CH₄, NaH. Answers: +1, +1, +1, -1.

oxidation_number_ions.name: Oxidation Number of Monatomic Ions
oxidation_number_ions.correct: For monatomic ions, the oxidation number equals the ionic charge. Na⁺ = +1, Cl⁻ = -1, Fe³⁺ = +3.

always zero.error: Zero is for neutral atoms/elements, not ions.
always zero.fix: Ions have gained or lost electrons. Their oxidation number = their charge.
always zero.action: Mg²⁺ has lost 2 electrons → oxidation number +2.

opposite to ionic charge.error: Oxidation number equals the charge, not the opposite.
opposite to ionic charge.fix: Fe³⁺ has oxidation number +3, not -3. Direct equality.
opposite to ionic charge.action: The sign and magnitude match: Ca²⁺ = +2, S²⁻ = -2.

equal to group number only.error: While group number predicts common charges, oxidation number equals actual charge.
equal to group number only.fix: Fe can be Fe²⁺ (+2) or Fe³⁺ (+3). Oxidation number matches the actual ion.
equal to group number only.action: Transition metals have variable oxidation states. Use the actual charge shown.

persistent.gap: You're not connecting ionic charge to oxidation number.
persistent.action: For 10 ions (Na⁺, Cl⁻, Fe²⁺, etc.), write the oxidation number. It equals the charge.

oxidation_number_neutral_compound.name: Oxidation Numbers in Neutral Compounds
oxidation_number_neutral_compound.correct: In a neutral compound, the sum of all oxidation numbers must equal zero. This allows calculation of unknown oxidation numbers.

sum equals the number of atoms.error: The sum relates to charge, not atom count.
sum equals the number of atoms.fix: Neutral compound = zero overall charge = zero sum of oxidation numbers.

each element has oxidation number zero.error: Individual elements have non-zero oxidation numbers; only the SUM is zero.
each element has oxidation number zero.fix: In H₂O: H = +1, O = -2. Sum = 0, but individual values are non-zero.

sum equals total electrons.error: Sum of oxidation numbers relates to charge balance, not electron count.
sum equals total electrons.fix: Oxidation numbers show relative electron distribution, not total electrons.
sum equals total electrons.action: Focus on charge balance: positive oxidation numbers balance negative ones.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how oxidation numbers balance in neutral compounds.
persistent.action: For CO₂, assign: C = ?, O = -2. Solve: x + 2(-2) = 0, so C = +4.

oxidation_number_polyatomic.name: Oxidation Numbers in Polyatomic Ions
oxidation_number_polyatomic.formula: Sum of oxidation numbers = ionic charge
oxidation_number_polyatomic.correct: In a polyatomic ion, the sum of oxidation numbers equals the overall ionic charge. For SO₄²⁻: S + 4(-2) = -2, so S = +6.

sum equals zero.error: Zero is for neutral compounds. Polyatomic ions have non-zero charge.
sum equals zero.fix: Sum = charge on the ion. SO₄²⁻ has charge -2, so oxidation numbers sum to -2.

each atom has the same oxidation number.error: Different elements have different oxidation numbers.
each atom has the same oxidation number.fix: In SO₄²⁻: S = +6, each O = -2. They're different.
each atom has the same oxidation number.action: Use rules: O is usually -2, then calculate the other element.

sum equals number of atoms.error: Sum relates to charge, not atom count.
sum equals number of atoms.action: Always match sum to the ionic charge shown in the formula.

persistent.gap: You're not balancing oxidation numbers with ionic charges.
persistent.action: Practice: find S in SO₃²⁻, N in NO₂⁻, Cr in Cr₂O₇²⁻.

oxidising_agent_definition.name: Oxidising Agent Definition
oxidising_agent_definition.correct: An oxidising agent causes another species to be oxidised (lose electrons). The oxidising agent itself is reduced (gains electrons). Its oxidation number decreases.

is itself oxidised.error: Reversed. The oxidising agent is REDUCED, not oxidised.
is itself oxidised.fix: Oxidising agent gains electrons (is reduced). It causes oxidation in others.
is itself oxidised.action: Think: oxidising agent TAKES electrons. Taking = gaining = reduction.

loses electrons.error: Oxidising agents GAIN electrons (they are reduced).
loses electrons.fix: The oxidising agent accepts electrons from the species it oxidises.
loses electrons.action: O₂ is an oxidising agent. It gains electrons: O₂ + 4e⁻ → 2O²⁻.

has its oxidation number increase.error: Oxidising agents have decreasing oxidation numbers (they gain electrons).
has its oxidation number increase.fix: Gaining electrons makes oxidation number more negative (decrease).
has its oxidation number increase.action: Cu²⁺ → Cu: oxidation number goes from +2 to 0. Decrease = reduction.

persistent.gap: You have oxidising agent behaviour backwards.
persistent.action: Remember: oxidising agent OXIDISES others but is itself REDUCED. It GAINS electrons.

reducing_agent_definition.name: Reducing Agent Definition
reducing_agent_definition.correct: A reducing agent causes another species to be reduced (gain electrons). The reducing agent itself is oxidised (loses electrons). Its oxidation number increases.

is itself reduced.error: Reversed. The reducing agent is OXIDISED, not reduced.
is itself reduced.fix: Reducing agent loses electrons (is oxidised). It causes reduction in others.
is itself reduced.action: Think: reducing agent GIVES electrons. Giving = losing = oxidation.

gains electrons.error: Reducing agents LOSE electrons (they are oxidised).
gains electrons.fix: The reducing agent donates electrons to the species it reduces.
gains electrons.action: Zn is a reducing agent. It loses electrons: Zn → Zn²⁺ + 2e⁻.

has its oxidation number decrease.error: Reducing agents have increasing oxidation numbers (they lose electrons).
has its oxidation number decrease.fix: Losing electrons makes oxidation number more positive (increase).
has its oxidation number decrease.action: Zn → Zn²⁺: oxidation number goes from 0 to +2. Increase = oxidation.

persistent.gap: You have reducing agent behaviour backwards.
persistent.action: Remember: reducing agent REDUCES others but is itself OXIDISED. It LOSES electrons.

identifying_agents_from_equation.name: Identifying Agents from Equations
identifying_agents_from_equation.correct: To identify agents: find which species has oxidation number INCREASE (reducing agent, is oxidised) and which has DECREASE (oxidising agent, is reduced).

the species that gains oxygen is the oxi.error: Focus on electron transfer, not oxygen atoms.
the species that gains oxygen is the oxi.fix: Track oxidation numbers. The species with DECREASING oxidation number is the oxidising agent.
the species that gains oxygen is the oxi.action: Assign oxidation numbers to all atoms. Find which change and in which direction.

the species on the left is always the re.error: Both reducing and oxidising agents are on the reactant (left) side.
the species on the left is always the re.fix: Both agents are reactants. One is oxidised, one is reduced.
the species on the left is always the re.action: In Zn + Cu²⁺ → Zn²⁺ + Cu: both Zn and Cu²⁺ are reactants. Zn is reducing agent, Cu²⁺ is oxidising agent.

the metal is always the oxidising agent.error: Metals typically LOSE electrons, making them reducing agents.
the metal is always the oxidising agent.fix: Metals donate electrons easily → usually reducing agents.
the metal is always the oxidising agent.action: Zn, Fe, Mg in reactions typically get oxidised = they're reducing agents.

persistent.gap: You can't systematically identify redox agents from equations.
persistent.action: Practice: for 5 reactions, assign all oxidation numbers, find changes, label agents.

conjugate_redox_pair.name: Conjugate Redox Pairs
conjugate_redox_pair.correct: A conjugate redox pair consists of an oxidised form and reduced form of the same element, differing by electrons. Example: Cu²⁺/Cu or Zn/Zn²⁺.

the oxidising agent and reducing agent.error: A redox couple is ONE element in two forms, not two different species.
the oxidising agent and reducing agent.fix: Cu²⁺/Cu is a couple (same element). Cu²⁺/Zn is NOT a couple (different elements).
the oxidising agent and reducing agent.action: Identify couples by finding the same element on both sides of the equation.

reactants and products.error: Not all reactants and products form redox couples.
reactants and products.fix: A redox couple has the same element with different oxidation states.
reactants and products.action: In Zn + Cu²⁺ → Zn²⁺ + Cu: couples are Zn/Zn²⁺ and Cu²⁺/Cu.

two species that react together.error: Couples are not reaction partners; they're forms of the same element.
two species that react together.fix: Zn and Cu²⁺ react together, but the couples are Zn/Zn²⁺ and Cu²⁺/Cu.
two species that react together.action: Look for the same element symbol on reactant and product sides.

persistent.gap: You're confusing redox couples with reactant pairs.
persistent.action: For any redox equation, draw arrows connecting same elements. Those pairs are couples.

half_equation_electrons.name: Electrons in Half-Equations
half_equation_electrons.formula: Left side = reduction, Right side = oxidation
half_equation_electrons.correct: In half-equations: electrons on the LEFT side means reduction (electrons gained). Electrons on the RIGHT side means oxidation (electrons lost).

electrons on left means oxidation.error: Reversed. Left-side electrons means the species GAINS electrons = reduction.
electrons on left means oxidation.fix: Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu. Electrons enter from left = electrons gained = reduction.
electrons on left means oxidation.action: Read the equation like a sentence: 'Cu²⁺ receives electrons to become Cu.'

electrons on right means reduction.error: Reversed. Right-side electrons means the species LOSES electrons = oxidation.
electrons on right means reduction.fix: Zn → Zn²⁺ + 2e⁻. Electrons exit to right = electrons lost = oxidation.
electrons on right means reduction.action: Read: 'Zn releases electrons to become Zn²⁺.'

electron position doesn't matter.error: Electron position directly indicates oxidation or reduction.
electron position doesn't matter.fix: Left = gain (reduction). Right = loss (oxidation). Position matters.
electron position doesn't matter.action: Draw an arrow showing electron flow direction in each half-equation.

persistent.gap: You can't read half-equations to determine oxidation or reduction.
persistent.action: Write 10 half-equations. For each, state: electrons left or right? Therefore oxidation or reduction?

redox_definition.title: Redox Reactions
redox_definition.content: Redox is short for reduction-oxidation. In every redox reaction, both reduction and oxidation occur simultaneously because electrons cannot be created or destroyed—they can only be transferred from one species to another. If one species loses electrons (oxidation), another must gain them (reduction).
keyPoints: Electrons are transferred, not created or destroyed
One species is oxidised while another is reduced

oxidation_definition.title: Oxidation
oxidation_definition.content: Oxidation is the loss of electrons. The mnemonic OIL RIG helps remember this: Oxidation Is Loss (of electrons). When a species is oxidised, its oxidation number increases. Despite the name, oxygen doesn't need to be involved—the modern definition is purely about electron transfer.
keyPoints: Doesn't require oxygen to be present

reduction_definition.title: Reduction
reduction_definition.content: Reduction is the gain of electrons. OIL RIG: Reduction Is Gain (of electrons). When a species is reduced, its oxidation number decreases. The term 'reduction' comes from the historical observation that metal ores were 'reduced' in mass when converted to pure metals.
keyPoints: Historically related to metal ore processing

oxidation_number_free_element.title: Oxidation Numbers of Free Elements
oxidation_number_free_element.content: Any element in its uncombined state has an oxidation number of zero. This applies to all elements whether they are monatomic (Fe, Cu, Na) or polyatomic molecules (O₂, H₂, N₂, S₈). The element hasn't lost or gained electrons yet.
keyPoints: Free element = not combined with other elements
Oxidation number = 0 for all free elements
Includes diatomic molecules: O₂, H₂, N₂, Cl₂
Includes metals: Fe, Cu, Zn, Mg, Na

oxidation_number_oxygen.title: Oxidation Number of Oxygen
oxidation_number_oxygen.content: Oxygen typically has an oxidation number of -2 in compounds. The exception is peroxides (compounds containing O-O bonds, like H₂O₂), where oxygen has an oxidation number of -1. Oxygen is the second most electronegative element, so it almost always has a negative oxidation number.
keyPoints: Never positive except with fluorine (very rare)

oxidation_number_hydrogen.title: Oxidation Number of Hydrogen
oxidation_number_hydrogen.content: Hydrogen typically has an oxidation number of +1 in compounds. The exception is metal hydrides (compounds with metals, like NaH, CaH₂), where hydrogen has an oxidation number of -1 because the metal is less electronegative than hydrogen.
keyPoints: Hydrogen has only one electron to lose or share
In most compounds, H shares its electron (acts as +1)

oxidation_number_ions.title: Oxidation Numbers of Ions
oxidation_number_ions.content: For monatomic ions, the oxidation number equals the ionic charge. Na⁺ has oxidation number +1, Cl⁻ has -1, Fe³⁺ has +3. This makes sense because the oxidation number represents the hypothetical charge if electrons were counted according to electronegativity.
keyPoints: Oxidation number = ionic charge for monatomic ions
Transition metals can have variable oxidation numbers

oxidation_number_neutral_compound.title: Oxidation Numbers in Neutral Compounds
oxidation_number_neutral_compound.content: In a neutral compound, the sum of all oxidation numbers must equal zero. This allows you to calculate unknown oxidation numbers using algebra. For example, in H₂O: 2(+1) + (-2) = 0. In CO₂: (+4) + 2(-2) = 0.
oxidation_number_neutral_compound.formula: Sum of all oxidation numbers = 0 (for neutral compounds)
keyPoints: Sum of oxidation numbers = 0 in neutral compounds
Use known values (H = +1, O = -2) to find unknowns
Account for subscripts (multiply by number of atoms)
This allows calculation of oxidation state for any element

oxidation_number_polyatomic.title: Oxidation Numbers in Polyatomic Ions
oxidation_number_polyatomic.content: In a polyatomic ion, the sum of oxidation numbers equals the overall ionic charge. For SO₄²⁻: S + 4(-2) = -2, so S = +6. For MnO₄⁻: Mn + 4(-2) = -1, so Mn = +7. This extends the neutral compound rule to charged species.
oxidation_number_polyatomic.formula: Sum of oxidation numbers = charge on the ion

oxidising_agent_definition.title: Oxidising Agents
oxidising_agent_definition.content: An oxidising agent causes another species to be oxidised (lose electrons). The oxidising agent itself is reduced (gains electrons). Its oxidation number decreases. Common oxidising agents include O₂, Cl₂, KMnO₄, and H₂O₂. They 'take' electrons from other species.
keyPoints: Common examples: O₂, Cl₂, KMnO₄, HNO₃

reducing_agent_definition.title: Reducing Agents
reducing_agent_definition.content: A reducing agent causes another species to be reduced (gain electrons). The reducing agent itself is oxidised (loses electrons). Its oxidation number increases. Common reducing agents include metals (Zn, Mg, Na) and some non-metals (C, H₂). They 'donate' electrons to other species.
keyPoints: Common examples: Zn, Mg, Na, C, H₂

identifying_agents_from_equation.title: Identifying Agents from Equations
identifying_agents_from_equation.content: To identify oxidising and reducing agents: (1) Assign oxidation numbers to all atoms, (2) Find which elements change oxidation number, (3) Increasing oxidation number = species is oxidised = it's the reducing agent, (4) Decreasing oxidation number = species is reduced = it's the oxidising agent.

conjugate_redox_pair.title: Conjugate Redox Pairs
conjugate_redox_pair.content: A conjugate redox pair (or redox couple) consists of the oxidised and reduced forms of the same element. They differ by electrons. Examples: Cu²⁺/Cu, Zn/Zn²⁺, Fe³⁺/Fe²⁺. In any redox reaction, there are two couples. The electrochemical series lists couples by reducing agent strength.
keyPoints: Same element in two oxidation states
Every redox reaction has two couples

half_equation_electrons.title: Electrons in Half-Equations
half_equation_electrons.content: Half-equations show either the oxidation or reduction part of a redox reaction. If electrons appear on the LEFT side, the equation shows reduction (electrons are gained). If electrons appear on the RIGHT side, the equation shows oxidation (electrons are lost).
